moves.1. e4 Nf6: 1...Nf6. I am unfamiliar with this opening. I have no idea why I played this.
moves.2. Nc3 e5 3. Bc4 Bc5 4. Nf3 d6: 4...d6 This Blocks off my Bishop, but helps guard the e-pawn. It also lets out my Light Squared Bishop.
moves.5. O-O: Both of My Bishops stare into the corner. Was Kingside the best way to Castle?
moves.6... Qd7: Lining up on diagonal, and getting Black closer to Castling Queenside.
moves.7. h3: Forcing me to make a choice: take or retreat.
moves.7... Bxh3: !? But take *what* is the real question! This move rips open White's King's cover.
moves.8. gxh3 Qxh3 9. Nh2: !! Until this move, White had been cramped with no hope of defense or counterplay. Now, White's Bishop and Queen are released, and spell trouble for Black.
moves.10. Nb5: Now I must move my King, losing Castling possibility.
moves.10... Kd7 11. Ng4 Nxe4 12. Bf3: ! Gets rid of my second attacker. Black's attack fizzles after the trade.
moves.12... Ng3: But Black doesn't want to trade -- he wants to give away a Rook and a Pawn.
moves.13. Nf6+ Kd8 14. Bxb7 c6: ! This cuts off the Bishop from the corner, and threatens mate.
moves.15. Qf3 g4 16. Nxg4 e4 17. Qf6+: Believe it or not, until this move, Black had planned move 16.
?? Further blocking the Bishop, but losing the Queen.
moves.21. Qc8+ Ke7 22. Qxh3 Nf4 23. Qh4+ f6 24: The rest of the game doesn't need annotation.
moves.26. Bxa8 Ne5 27. Qg7+ Nf7 28. Bxd5 Bxh2: And here it is. An attack on the stronghold proved disastrous. Please leave comments, and thanks for reading!

gameName: Training annotation #4 -- Like water against rock
